author: potuz
content:
<@415548822983278593> can you expand on your last comment?
> actually both ePBS and DE reduce the ratio of propagation to execution, so they would tighten the (relative) data constraints on BALs

author: ansgar.eth
content:
I didn't think it through very deeply yet, so this framing is probably not precise

but basically, today the max time for propagation and max time for execution are the same. whereas after ePBS/DE, there is more time for execution in the slot than for propagation. so in relative terms, data becomes more precious. and so the data part of BALs becomes more burdensome

author: ansgar.eth
content: basically if you think about a "gas price per byte of data" and a "gas price per ms of block processing", ePBS/DE will change that ratio and make block processing cheaper relative to data. So the fact that any state access (used to only add ms to block processing) now also contributes to data, is more "costly" than it would be without ePBS/DE

author: ansgar.eth
content:
I am pretty certain that BALs will still be net useful, but they will be a bit less useful than they would be today.

Thought experiment to illustrate that: Imagine ePBS with 1min slot time, but PTC deadline already 1s after block is published. In that world, we would not want to do BALs, because you basically have infinite time for execution, but data is very limited.
